bibl.title: Nishikawa Mamoru v. T.W. Lynch. Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus
In the Matter of the Application of NISHIKAWA MAMORU For Writ of Habeas Corpus
T.W. Lynch, Acting Commissioner of Immigration, Respondent.
Comes now NISHIKAWA MAMORU by his attorney, Winter S. Martin, and respectfully shows to the Court:

That your petitioner is a citizen of the Empire of Japan, who came to the United States on board the Steamer "Fushimi Maru" arriving at the Port of Seattle October 9, 1918. That upon October 10th he was committed to the Providence Hospital for treatment and while there and without a passport or other permission to enter the United States, or to be or remain therein, left the hospital and did not return to his ship. That he remained continuously in the United States until the 3d day of November, 1921, when he was taken into custody upon a warrant for deportation by the Department of Labor at Cosmopolis, Washington.
That a hearing was had upon the departmental warrant for
deportation, and your petitioner's deportation was ordered. That thereafter the record was made up and the papers forwarded to the Honorable Commissioner of Immigration at Washington, D.C.
That thereafter said Honorable Commissioner and the Secretary of Labor ordered your petitioner's deportation pursuant to the hearing held at the Port of Seattle aforesaid.

That since your petitioner's arrest and detention on November 5th he has been detained in the United States Immigration Station at Seattle, where he now is. That under said warrant of deportation, unless restrained by this Honorable Court, your petitioner will be placed on board ship November 26, 1921, and will be by said Commissioner of Immigration and his deputies unlawfully deported to Japan.
That in all respects his arrest, detention and imprisonment is illegal and without warrant or authority.
1. That a writ of habeas corpus may be issued to your said petitioner and that he may be discharged from said illegal restraint and unlawful arrest;

2, That pending a hearing upon an application for this writ of habeas corpus that said Thomas W. Lynch, Acting Commissioner of Immigration, and his deputies, be hereby enjoined and restrained from deporting your petitioner from Seattle to the Empire of Japan;
3. That an order to show cause issue forthwith directed to the said Thomas W. Lynch, Acting Commissioner of Immigration, requiring him to be and appear in the above entitled Court, at a
time to be fixed by this Honorable Court, to show cause, if any he have, why the said writ of habeas corpus shall not be granted.
UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, Western District of Washington, Northern Division.
NISHIKAWA MAMORU, being first duly sworn by and through an interpreter, upon his oath states:
That he has heard read to him this Petition for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, and that the facts therein stated are true.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 25th day of November, 1921.
Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
Filed in the United States District Court
